title: 110_hr2561
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fast and Secure Travel at the Borders Act of 2007" or the "FAST Borders Act of 2007". The findings of the 9/11 Commission are also included. The 9/11 Commission recommends expanding the terrorist travel intelligence program, using information systems to detect potential threats at various border points, and implementing a comprehensive screening system led by the Department of Homeland Security. The Department of Homeland Security recommends implementing a screening system that looks for identifiable suspects or indicators of risk to intercept potential threats at border points. SEC. 3. AUTOMATED TARGETING SYSTEM FOR PERSONS ENTERING OR DEPARTING THE UNITED STATES. The Secretary of Homeland Security may establish an automated system for enforcing US laws related to antiterrorism and border security for screening individuals entering or leaving the country. An administrative process must be in place for individuals to correct any information in the system, with no private right of action or court jurisdiction based on these provisions. The section allows for the establishment of an automated system for enforcing US laws related to antiterrorism and border security. It also includes provisions for a corrective administrative process and authorizes appropriations for its implementation. Additionally, it clarifies that existing Federal and State laws protecting against unauthorized collection or release of personal records are not affected. SEC. 435. PASSENGER AND CREW MANIFESTS FOR VESSELS, VEHICLES, AND AIRCRAFT ARRIVING IN OR DEPARTING FROM THE UNITED STATES. This section introduces new requirements for passenger and crew manifests for transportation entering or leaving the US. The Commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection may require vessels, vehicles, and aircraft arriving in or departing from the United States to transmit passenger and crew manifests containing specific information. Manifests must be transmitted in advance in the manner prescribed by regulations. The Commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection may require passenger and crew manifests with specific information for vessels, vehicles, and aircraft arriving in or departing from the United States. Information required includes complete name, date of birth, citizenship, gender, passport number, country of issuance, and other necessary details to enforce customs, immigration, transportation security, and national security laws. Failure to provide accurate information may result in civil penalties. The Commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection may require commercial carriers to provide passenger name record information for arrivals and departures from the United States. Failure to comply may result in civil penalties of up to $5,000 per person for inaccurate or incomplete information. The Commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection may impose civil penalties of up to $5,000 for failure to provide passenger name record information as required. Information from passenger manifests can be shared with other government agencies for national security purposes. The Commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection consults with stakeholders from the transportation industry to assess the economic impact of regulations before issuing them. This section does not weaken any laws protecting against unauthorized collection or release of personal records.
